Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Robert Noyce Teaching Fellowship project at California State University-Bakersfield (CSUB) is designed to address a pressing need evolving from the misalignment of traditional baccalaureate programs and California's subject matter requirements (requiring more science breadth preparation) for teachers. A credential track within an MS in Science Education has been developed to address this problem. It provides science breadth, pedagogy and credential coursework for individuals with existing science degrees and represents a novel approach to recruiting and training science teachers by targeting enhanced preparation specifically towards individuals for whom teaching was not an initial career choice.

Intellectual Merit: Four main aspects of the program are being studied: Recruitment, Retention, Preparation and Teacher Quality. An evaluation of effectiveness is undertaken by comparing characteristics of the Noyce Fellows with science teachers prepared in traditional credential programs.

Broader Impacts are realized as the program can potentially serve as a model in California and nationwide for programs aiming to increase the pool of science teachers by attracting individuals from non-teaching backgrounds and enhancing the science breadth and pedagogy preparation of these individuals compared to both traditional and existing alternative routes to the credential. The Noyce Fellowship program at CSU Bakersfield is serving ten Teaching Fellows in two cohorts, impacting approximately 5,400 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:  This program tried a novel approach to recruiting and training science teachers, targeting individuals for whom teaching was not an initial career choice.  Given the small size of our program, our main venue for dissemination has been the Annual Noyce Summits.  We prepared posters for the Noyce Summits in 2013, 2014 and 2016.  (There was no summit in 2015, and by 2017, the program was effectively ended).  While our poster in 2013 was simply an explanation of our new program, in 2014 we reported on the use of Advanced Placement (AP) conferences as an addition to our program to provide Fellows with additional pedagogy in science as well as preparing them to teach these challenging courses as they began their teaching careers.  In 2016, one of our fellows reported on the joint experiences of several fellows who, rather unexpectedly, ended up teaching in local middle & junior high schools, with a discussion of the well-known decline in science performance during middle school in our local context.  In addition, the program at California State University, Bakersfield (CSUB) has participated each year of its existence to the larger Noyce datasets being compiled at the national level to help understand recruitment, preparation and retention of science teachers.

 

Broader Impacts:  Our main broader impact, like all Noyce projects, involves the development of highly qualified science teachers who, in turn, impact the communities they teach in.  In addition, our program targeted individuals who otherwise may not have become science teachers because of the State of California’s unusual subject matter requirement hurdle, focusing on both career changers and individuals with traditional science degrees.  This is an important impact because it expands the limited pool of qualified science teachers in California by tapping an audience that was unlikely to become teachers without the CSUB Noyce Program.

 

Project Outcomes:

            Unfortunately, we fell far short of our initial goal of 20 Fellows completing the program.  We recruited and provided fellowships to 14 individuals.  Although we targeted “non-traditional” teaching candidates, we did not exclude those with more traditional teaching backgrounds.  A surprising finding during our recruiting period was that the program was not attractive to individuals pursuing more traditional routes to the California Teaching credential.  We had expected to recruit a few top students from our existing science teacher preparation program, but only one student from this program chose to become a Fellow.  This was largely due to the desire to enter the workforce and begin earning a full salary quickly: the financial incentive supplied by the program combined with the promise of a higher future salary after earning the Master’s Degree were not enough to counterbalance the more immediate effect of lost salary for the extra year of preparation required.

            Demographically, our fellows were not as diverse as we had hoped, given that we are a Hispanic-Serving Institution:  we provided fellowships to one African American, three Latino/a, and ten Caucasian students, which is clearly different than the representation in our undergraduate population.  We had better representation by gender, with eight female and six male Fellows in the program, roughly equal to our undergraduate population’s gender diversity.  The diversity, both racial and gender, did reflect our applicant pool, as we did not turn away any applicants that met our basic requirements.

            Ten Fellows have completed the program, and all are currently teaching.  One additional fellow is currently teaching while completing the program, and is expected to complete all requirements by the end of the Spring 2018 semester.  Three Fellows left the program before completion and are currently in various stages of paying back the funds they received.  Additionally, we had three students enter the program without receiving fellowships:  two were unable to accept because of issues with citizenship status, while the other rejected the fellowship due to concerns about meeting the post-graduation requirements of the program.  Two of these three completed the program.

Finally, we did well in reaching “non-traditional” teaching candidates.  Only one of the fellows came to us from our BA in Natural Sciences program, the degree at CSUB designed specifically for individuals pursuing a science teaching career.  All of the other Fellows came to the program with traditional Bachelor’s degrees in the sciences (six in general Bioscience, two in Chemistry, two in Geoscience and one each with Enology, Neuroscience and Optometry degrees).  Of the fourteen Fellowships awarded, eight were to career changers, with an average of 8 years (range:2-18) of previous employment outside education/academia.  In addition, two students switched from traditional MS degrees in science (one Biology, one Geology) to the MS in Science Education.  One career-changing fellow came to the program with a completed MS in Microbiology.
